<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Antoninianus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Pupienus  
A.D. 238 (April/June), issued by Balbinus and Pupienus  
Silver; diam. 2.4 cm; 4.49 g  
Mint: Rome  
Obverse: Bust of Pupienus right, radiate crown, cuirass and paludamentum  
Inscribed: IMP CAES PVPIEN MAXIMVS AVG  
Reverse: Hands clasped  
Inscribed: PATRES SENATVS  
RIC IV 11; BMCRE VI 92–94; axis: 6:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Martin A. Ryerson, 1922.4895

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Appointed by the Senate in response to the murder of Gordian I and Gordian II in March A.D. 238, the coemperors D. Caelius Calvinus Balbinus and M. Clodius Pupienus Maximus were to reign as truly equal partners—a novel idea in Roman government. They even shared the office of pontifex maximus. The reverse image of the coin shows their alleged accord; the inscription calls them the “fathers of the Senate.” The title Pater Senatus had first been granted to Commodus by the Senate in 182, out of terror of reprisals after a failed assassination attempt. These cofathers, at least, tried to deserve the honor. Pupienus, an experienced military man, was spared the need to face the usurper Maximinus Thrax (“the Thracian”), who was murdered by his own troops that June. His portraits, as on this coin, suggest the weight of responsibility and a “haunted apprehension.” An insurrection by the Praetorian Guard—ostensibly the imperial bodyguards—ended the joint reign by fire and the sword. The Senate replaced them with Gordian III (see cat. 66, Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Gordian III), bringing that year’s total to six emperors.  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Imperator Caesar Pupienus Maximus Augustus

Susan Wood provides a formal analysis of Pupienus’s surviving portraits: Wood, Roman Portrait Sculpture, pp. 34–38.
